results.title: The Seventh mandarin
results.creator_credit: Sam Weiss, Nick Bosustow, Xerox Films and Stephen Bosustow Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Desire to read”.
Long ago in a walled palace lived a Chiense emperor, guarded and guided by seven assistants called mandarins. None of them ever set foot outside the palace and they knew nothing of the people until the seventh and youngest mandarin ventured out one night…Based on the picture book by Jane Yolen.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sam Weiss, Nick Bosustow, Xerox Films and Stephen Bosustow Productions

results.title: Donna Karan. Vivienne Westwood
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Reeder, Lida Piompino, Yana Gould, Michelle Brown and Video Fashion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Designers”.
Donna Karan: U.S. designer Donna Karan discusses the trademarks of her signature brand and DKNY - luxury, comfort, sensuality, strength and femininity to create a timeless look that transcends any fashion trends - defined by the narrator as a combination of modern luxury and American sensibility. Karan’s history as a designer is covered, as well as interviews with fashion magazine editors, models, fans and photographers. “Vivienne Westwood”: Britain’s most controversial designer is undoubtedly Vivienne Westwood, a designer who attracts responses such as innovative, controversial, sexy and unorthodox. Westwood - normally reticent about discussing issues such as fashion talks about her relationship with Malcolm MacLaren in the 70’s, the breakup and change in focus to the deconstruction of garments, and her passion for the 17-19th centuries. Like the section on Donna Karan, the narrator attempts to capture the tenets of Westwood’s design and looks at areas such as the corset, platform shoes, distorting the female form and symbols of bondage. Both feature plenty of catwalk footage of the designs in action.

results.title: Beyond our vision
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Developing image”.
The need for accurate recording through photographs is examined, in both the past and the present. The program explores Western survey photography, including an original Western survey album used to persuade Congress to make Yellowstone National Park, Eadweard Muybridge’s stop-action photography and Landsat satellite imagery. Photography can now provide viewers insight into places, objects and events, beyond their personal experience.

results.title: Expressing a twentieth century vision
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “The Developing image”.
This program probes how the photograph has been used as a metaphor to describe the photographer’s inner state. This is in contrast to traditional approaches to realistic photography. Individual photographers discuss the use of metaphor in their own experiences and works.

results.title: The Camera image: more than a record
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Developing image”.
This program examines the pre-history of photography, discussing the concepts of visual perspective, mechanical devices leading to the invention of the camera, and the cultural needs that generated the invention of photography. The special qualities of the camera and its artistic capabilities are discussed.

results.title: The Developing image
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description: Explores the marvellous invention of the camera, using colour and music to evoke the period. This series takes viewers from the daguerreotype to wet plate to tintype and onwards examining hundreds of exemplary photographs. It dramatically depicts various themes in the history of photography.

results.title: A Conversation with Wilson Bryan Key
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “The Developing image”.
Dr. Key is a professor of Media Studies and president of Media Probe, a centre for the study of Media. Dr. Key attempts to awaken the public to the real message behind the innumerable photographic images which surround us. This fascinating discussion focuses on subliminal advertising, and how millions of dollars are spent each year for the solitary purpose of persuading consumers to buy a product.

results.title: Light from within
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “The Developing image”.
Examines the artistic aspects of photography, comparing it with trends in modern art, and deals with early and contemporary creative photography. The trend towards graphic experimentation is examined through a discussion with contemporary photographers who are leading practitioners in their fields.

results.title: Revenge of the river gods
results.creator_credit: Qi Kejun, Xue Song, Liu Chun, Lin Xiezhong, Wei Bin, Yu Bo, Zhao Shujing, Chen Meng, Yuan Zhengming, ABC-TV (Australia), Southern Star Entertainment and CCTV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Dragon stirs”.
Part two of a four-part series about China. The Yangtze River floods of the summer of 1998 destroyed 50 million homes and devastated 21 million hectares of farmland. It was China’s worst recorded flood in at least 50 years lasting for several weeks and affecting many villages and cities. Beijing reacted by immobilizing three-quarter million soldiers into the biggest force since liberation in 1949. This is not the first time the Yangtze (known by the Chinese as the “Mother of China”) has caused havoc through flooding. However this time it would appear that not only is the unusual weather conditions to blame, but destruction of the environment over time through damming, re-routing and mismanaging of the Yangtze, forest-clearing and filling-in of natural lakes in the Yangtze River Basin and greed, dishonesty and corruption by provincial and city officials responsible for building the dams have all contributed to this unprecedented natural disaster. The program features some amazing images of the floods and includes actual footage of many of the search and rescue efforts performed by the soldiers. It also demonstrates the remarkable fortitude and commitment by both civilians and soldiers in their mighty struggle to hold back the unrelenting waters. Contains b&w archival footage. Narrated by Peter George and Diana McLean. Commentary in English with occasional dialogue in Mandarin with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Qi Kejun, Xue Song, Liu Chun, Lin Xiezhong, Wei Bin, Yu Bo, Zhao Shujing, Chen Meng, Yuan Zhengming, ABC-TV (Australia), Southern Star Entertainment and CCTV

This is not the first time the Yangtze (known by the Chinese as the “Mother of China”) has caused havoc through flooding. However this time it would appear that not only is the unusual weather conditions to blame, but destruction of the environment over time through damming, re-routing and mismanaging of the Yangtze, forest-clearing and filling-in of natural lakes in the Yangtze River Basin and greed, dishonesty and corruption by provincial and city officials responsible for building the dams have all contributed to this unprecedented natural disaster. The program features some amazing images of the floods and includes actual footage of many of the search and rescue efforts performed by the soldiers. It also demonstrates the remarkable fortitude and commitment by both civilians and soldiers in their mighty struggle to hold back the unrelenting waters. Contains b&w archival footage. Narrated by Peter George and Diana McLean. Commentary in English with occasional dialogue in Mandarin with English subtitles.
